attributes.action: Data quoted as facts in political ads must be supported by documentary evidence
attributes.additional_details: The Code of Advertising Practice says "marketers must hold documentary evidence to prove all claims, whether direct or implied, that are capable of objective substantiation" and "no marketing communication should mislead, or be likely to mislead, by inaccuracy, ambiguity, exaggeration, omission or otherwise". The FCA requires adverts for financial products to be "clear, fair and not misleading". Similar rules should apply to political advertising where factual claims are being made.
attributes.background: The EU referendum campaign was marred by misleading presentation of data, most notably the "£350m a week paid to the EU" which the   ONS publicly refuted. There should be a requirement that data presented as fact should be capable of objective verification, and this should be enforced independently.
